comments.body:
As a general comment, I think it would maybe make more sense to have naming conventions:
issuer_subject_key_identifier
issuer_subject_name
issuer_serial_number

As that's typically how that information is presented about a certificate. I haven't finished reviewing the changes though, so I realize there may be backwards compatibility/consistency issues leading to the authority_ naming convention.
After reviewing the rest I realize this was for consistency with the CSR additions.

I mainly stuck to the names from the RFC (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.1). There's no backwards compatibility to be considered here, so we can also change the names, but I'm not sure whether it's a good idea to choose something completely different.

That's what I get for writing comments on the doc before actually finishing reading all the code - I forgot those pieces of information are even defined, so I was thinking that it was identifying issuer based on key identifier, then displaying information about the issuer from _there_. Thumbs up on the naming.

Interestingly, the cryptography.io docs were very confusing on `authority_cert_issuer`. The type was specified as `GeneralNames`, but the description says it is a `Name` ([source](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/x509/reference/#cryptography.x509.AuthorityKeyIdentifier.authority_cert_issuer)). I skimmed over the type and started implementing the `Name` approach, only then to find out during testing that it didn't want that. The result is pyca/cryptography#4973 :)
